results.abstract: Scientists report two years of careful analysis of radar signatures of moon transmitted by small Defense Department spacecraft suggests presence of water ice in permanently cold shadows of deep basin near lunar south pole; say survey by Clementine spacececraft seems to reveal vast landscape of approximately 3,000 square miles in which ice crystals are mixed with dirt in kind of permafrost that is presumably residue of moisture from comets striking moon over last three billion years; photos; diagrams (M)

headline.main: The Moon May Have Water, And Many New Possibilities

results.snippet: Scientists think they have detected water on the Moon, and suddenly visions of people living in lunar colonies and stopping off there to refuel on the way to Mars seem a little less farfetched.    After two years of careful analysis, scientists said...
results.lead_paragraph: Scientists think they have detected water on the Moon, and suddenly visions of people living in lunar colonies and stopping off there to refuel on the way to Mars seem a little less farfetched. After two years of careful analysis, scientists said yesterday that radar signals from an American spacecraft indicated the Moon was not as bone-dry as is usually thought. The peculiar radar signatures suggested the presence of water ice in the permanently cold shadows of a deep basin near the lunar south pole.

results.abstract: Neither fantasies nor fears of residents of Taszar, Hungary, have materialized during year in which village served as base for US military operations in Bosnia; many had dreams of instant wealth from world's richest army, and others fears about dive in moral standards as free-wheeling GI's behaved as depicted in Hollywood movies; map (M)

headline.main: G.I. Charm Overcomes Anxieties In Hungary

results.snippet: The prospect of thousands of American soldiers setting up base camp in this tiny village that does not rate a dot on most maps sent dizzying visions through many minds here. On one hand there were dreams of instant wealth from the world's richest...
results.lead_paragraph: The prospect of thousands of American soldiers setting up base camp in this tiny village that does not rate a dot on most maps sent dizzying visions through many minds here. On one hand there were dreams of instant wealth from the world's richest army, on the other worries about a dive in moral standards as free-wheeling G.I.'s behaved as depicted in Hollywood movies. Now, after the town has served as the logistical base for the United States military operations in Bosnia for nearly a year, neither the fantasies nor fears of Taszar's residents have materialized.

results.abstract: Clouds delay landing of space shuttle Columbia, giving Dr Story Musgrave, the world's oldest astronaut, one more day in orbit before he ends his flying career (M)

headline.main: Clouds Force NASA to Delay Shuttle Landing by One Day

results.snippet: Clouds moved in at the last minute today and delayed the space shuttle Columbia's return to Earth, offering the world's oldest astronaut one more day in orbit before he ends his flying career.    ''Give me another day up here and I'll take every...
results.lead_paragraph: Clouds moved in at the last minute today and delayed the space shuttle Columbia's return to Earth, offering the world's oldest astronaut one more day in orbit before he ends his flying career. ''Give me another day up here and I'll take every second of it,'' the astronaut, Dr. Story Musgrave, 61, assured Mission Control.

results.abstract: Manning of new Russian space station with an American astronaut and two Russians is delayed for five months, until Oct 1998, because financial difficulties are preventing the Russians from launching a service module on time; completion of the station on time is still possible (M)

headline.main: Russian Economic Crisis Delays Crew's Arrival on Space Station

results.snippet: The international space station will fly without a crew for months longer than planned because of Russia's economic crisis, a top NASA official said today, though completion of the station on time is still possible.    A NASA astronaut, William...
results.lead_paragraph: The international space station will fly without a crew for months longer than planned because of Russia's economic crisis, a top NASA official said today, though completion of the station on time is still possible. A NASA astronaut, William Shepherd, and two Russians were supposed to be the station's first settlers in May 1998, six months after the launching of its first component. But now they will not get there until October 1998 at the earliest because of the Russians' inability to launch a service module on time, said the manager of the space station program, Randy Brinkley.

results.abstract: John Russell discusses some of year's notable books on art (Special Christmas issue of Book Review) (L)
results.snippet: Contrary to rumor, the good art book is not an endangered species. There are new authors, new subjects and new formats. There are new prices, too, but they are in line with the exigencies of the day.    THE PANORAMA OF THE RENAISSANCE. Edited by...
results.lead_paragraph: Contrary to rumor, the good art book is not an endangered species. There are new authors, new subjects and new formats. There are new prices, too, but they are in line with the exigencies of the day. THE PANORAMA OF THE RENAISSANCE. Edited by Margaret Aston. (Abrams, $45.) THE ART OF RENAISSANCE ROME, 1400-1600. By Loren Partridge. (Perspectives/Abrams, paper, $16.95.) A conspicuous novelty in the art book business is what might be called the mega-magazine. This is the book, large or small, in which the traditional primacy of text over image is loosened, broken up and turned inside out. The picture researcher is now the impresario, with material that is as exuberant as it is diverse. Layout and image lead the dance. The text, though tightly written and not scanted, does not run on. There are maps, plans, engravings, photographs, illustrations, family trees and chronologies to vary the menu. Thumbnail biographical dictionaries chase away the chore of remembering who is who.

results.abstract: Space Shuttle Columbia and its five astronauts return to earth with landing in Florida, ending longest shuttle flight ever; space shuttle was aloft nearly 18 days (M)

headline.main: Longest Space Shuttle Flight Ends With Dawn Landing in Florida

results.snippet: After nearly 18 days aloft, the space shuttle Columbia and its five astronauts returned to Earth today at dawn, ending the longest shuttle flight ever.    The shuttle swooped through a slightly hazy sky and touched down here at 6:49 A.M., minutes...
results.lead_paragraph: After nearly 18 days aloft, the space shuttle Columbia and its five astronauts returned to Earth today at dawn, ending the longest shuttle flight ever. The shuttle swooped through a slightly hazy sky and touched down here at 6:49 A.M., minutes before sunrise. Fog and low clouds had thwarted landing attempts on the two previous mornings.

results.abstract: Article lists several children's books appropriate for Christmas gifts (M)
results.snippet: ''Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows,'' the English poet John Betjeman wrote in ''Summoned by Bells.'' The following 10 illustrated children's books are silent, and they smell only faintly...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows,'' the English poet John Betjeman wrote in ''Summoned by Bells.'' The following 10 illustrated children's books are silent, and they smell only faintly of printer's ink and binding glue. But they contain sights that may measure out pleasure to children, and to grown-ups looking for shafts of light in the dark of reason. THE STORY OF LITTLE BABAJI. By Helen Bannerman. Illustrated by Fred Marcellino. (Michael di Capua/ HarperCollins Publishers; $14.95). In which an Indian boy goes for a dangerous walk in the jungle, and Helen Bannerman's classic ''Story of Little Black Sambo'' is retold without its unfortunate colonialist overtones. Fred Marcellino's tigers look delicious enough to be devoured even before they melt into butter for Babaji's pancakes.

results.abstract: Human reaction to long periods of weightlessness remains major problem for scientists to overcome before longer voyages in future; muscles, heart function, blood flow, red blood cell production and immune system are usually weakened when astronauts first step back onto Earth's surface, but one of worst repercussions is continuous loss of bone mineral inspace, especially from hip and lower spine; solution may be low-tech hard exercise, orbital equivalent of pumping iron; emerging consensus is that endurance exercises stressing aerobics and stamina must be supplanted by strenuous workouts that increase mechanical stress on muscles; photos; diagram of idea for tandem cycle; Drs Frank M Sulzman, Kennedy M Baldwin and Michael C Greenisen comment; understanding is also aided by experiences of astronauts Norman Thagard and Shannon Lucid aboard Russian space station Mir (M)

headline.main: Space Doctors Decide Pumping Iron Is Key To Astronauts' Health

results.snippet: AS clues of ice on the Moon and ancient life on Mars stir dreams of human explorers trekking across space and perhaps even setting up distant colonies one day, scientists are grappling with a still daunting problem: keeping astronauts healthy for...
results.lead_paragraph: AS clues of ice on the Moon and ancient life on Mars stir dreams of human explorers trekking across space and perhaps even setting up distant colonies one day, scientists are grappling with a still daunting problem: keeping astronauts healthy for long periods in space. New research on how people react to long spans of weightlessness is driving home a range of health risks, especially ones that affect the body upon return to gravity's pull. Muscles, heart function, blood flow, red blood cell production and the immune system are usually weakened when astronauts first step back onto the Earth's surface.

results.abstract: New York Giants are involved in intense contract negotiations with guard Lance Smith; Giants cut Smith's salary from $1.1 million to $350,000, during off season, but he has been one of team's most consistent players this season (M)

headline.main: Smith Feels A Huge Block From Giants

results.snippet: In the remaining days of the season, the Giants are trying to take care of some final issues involving their coaches and, of course, their players. One of those issues concerns guard Lance Smith, who is involved in intense and sensitive discussions...
results.lead_paragraph: In the remaining days of the season, the Giants are trying to take care of some final issues involving their coaches and, of course, their players. One of those issues concerns guard Lance Smith, who is involved in intense and sensitive discussions with the Giants involving his contract. The Giants and Smith's agent, Peter Schaffer, have been discussing Smith's situation for more than a month. It stems from a move the team made this past off season when it asked Smith to take a pay cut of about $1 million, from $1.1 million to $350,000. Then, Smith was replaced in the starting lineup by Rob Zatechka. As usual with Smith, he handled both things with class and did not once publicly complain, although being asked to take a pay cut and being benched was surely not pleasant for him.

results.abstract: Danielle Bernstein letter on article on astronaut Shannon Lucid in Nov 24 special magazine issue on female icons; photo (S)
results.snippet: What better role model could there be than the astronaut Shannon Lucid? By focusing on mathematics and science, women can have engrossing careers. And who knows? The best and brightest can even shoot for the moon -- the real one.    DANIELLE...
results.lead_paragraph: What better role model could there be than the astronaut Shannon Lucid? By focusing on mathematics and science, women can have engrossing careers. And who knows? The best and brightest can even shoot for the moon -- the real one. DANIELLE BERNSTEIN Union, N.J.

results.abstract: Two large chunks of Challenger wash ashore at Cocoa Beach, Florida, nearly eleven years after space shuttle exploded on takeoff at Cape Canaveral, killing seven astronauts; photo (S)

headline.main: Challenger Parts Wash Ashore Almost 11 Years After Explosion

results.snippet: Nearly 11 years after the space shuttle Challenger exploded, two large chunks of the left wing washed ashore today, apparently the biggest pieces discovered since NASA closed the investigation into the accident in 1986.    Officials of the National...
results.lead_paragraph: Nearly 11 years after the space shuttle Challenger exploded, two large chunks of the left wing washed ashore today, apparently the biggest pieces discovered since NASA closed the investigation into the accident in 1986. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said they were surprised by today's news, especially the size and fairly good condition of the barnacle-encrusted metal. One piece was 6 feet to 8 1/2 feet wide, 13 1/2 feet long and 2 feet to 2 1/2 feet thick; the other was about 6 inches wide and 5 feet long.

results.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews movie The Evening Star, written and directed by Robert Harling and starring Shirley MacLaine; photo (M)

headline.main: She's Back, Still Coping, Still Crying

results.snippet: ''The Evening Star,'' the wayward and needless sequel to ''Terms of Endearment,'' is so desperate to touch base with its predecessor that the new story's characters often reach for their scrapbooks to summon memories of the first film's dead heroine....
results.lead_paragraph: ''The Evening Star,'' the wayward and needless sequel to ''Terms of Endearment,'' is so desperate to touch base with its predecessor that the new story's characters often reach for their scrapbooks to summon memories of the first film's dead heroine. Debra Winger's Emma, available only in snapshots and glowing references, is invoked over and over in a film that has few better ways to spend its time. ''The Evening Star'' wobbles along for well over two hours and still seems uneventful, since it does little more than watch Aurora Greenway (Shirley MacLaine) cope pluckily with her grandmotherly problems. Aurora, the Dolly Levi of suburban Houston, still has a big retinue of friends, servants and admirers. She also has the three grown children whom Emma left behind, and shepherding them provides many opportunities for cracker-barrel wisdom. For instance: ''I have come to the conclusion that there is no such thing as a mistake. I think we all create what we need.'' And, ''When you stop trying, you fade away.''

results.abstract: Advice on how to evaluate worth of health club before making long-term financial commitment; photo (M)

headline.main: Resolving to Sweat, At Least Until February

results.snippet: Q. I'm determined to join a health club and get in shape in the new year. But is there a way to do it without making a long-term financial commitment?    A. When the holiday bingeing season officially ends on Thursday, listen closely and you'll hear...
results.lead_paragraph: Q. I'm determined to join a health club and get in shape in the new year. But is there a way to do it without making a long-term financial commitment? A. When the holiday bingeing season officially ends on Thursday, listen closely and you'll hear a great sucking sound, as countless Americans rush from their La-Z-Boys to health clubs and fitness spas.
